featureType.name: qgis_irmt_5f67abd7_1a6b_4da1_9221_c5600b13815d
featureType.title: SARA_Ecuador_Risk_Integrated_27122015
featureType.abstract: The following is an integrated earthquake risk assessment for Ecuador at the Parroquia (P3) level of geography. This assessment is a "work in progress" as weights will be applied to the data. The latter is being conducted within the respective country. Integrated risk is defined here as the combination of average annual losses to residential infrastructure with a composite index of social vulnerability. A composite index of social vulnerability is a combination of data that aims to measure characteristics within social systems that create the potential for loss and the differential ability to mitigate, respond to, and recover from damaging earthquake events. An integrated risk index provides a "broad brush" approach to highlighting areas where earthquake losses are most likely to occur coupled with the location of populations that are least likely to be able to be able to cope with such losses.
